text: The Galvo Speed is nice, but at the end of the day, the power is weak and the image quality is awful. The other add-ons seem like an identity crisis for compact and mobile unit. Just got the D1, and quite frankly its pretty mobile should I find the need to move it. The D1 has a slightly smaller list price for 10w vs 1.5w at the laser, and has half the light beam diameter. I think anybody who dropped bank on this wizard gadgetry would be buying on impulse, but quickly have buyers remorse after the low quality results become the apparent norm.

text:
I received this laser this week and I have to say it is a sexy POS.  They say it works now with lightburn, well it does not.    I have had nothing but problems with it.  It crashes into the wall all the time.  When you tell it to home, it crashes into the wall.  If you try to frame your work to tell where you need to put you material, it crashes into the wall.  There are no limit switches on this laser so it has no idea where it is.  If you want to put your work in the middle of the field, well good luck.  I tried everything and it would only work in the upper left corner.  There is no emergency stop switch, so if you have a problem you have to fumble  around for the power switch.  Not something you want to do if you have a real problem.  I ordered the rotary with this laser but did not get it.  I had to contact support to find out that it was on backorder, and they never even thought to email me to let me know.  There is no factory air assist with this laser, and that would defiantly come in handy.  Their setup video is horrible.  It moves so fast that you can't really tell what they are doing and what part that are using.  I have to say DON'T buy this if you are new to laser engraving, and even if you are a seasoned  person it will be hard to get it to work properly.  Do yourself a favor and stay away from this laser.  Sorry to put this up but I think it will help a lot of people.  This is not a well thought out machine. Yeah it looks sexy and well built but it's not worth the price at all.  I will be getting an Ortur for sure.
I do think that you can learn a lot from this channel though.  He really seems to know his stuff.  Keep the videos coming, and thank you for all you do for this hobby.
video: Is this the BEST budget Laser Engraver? Ortur Laser Master Engrave 2 Review

text: I got a little diode cnc laser like this a few years back I had fun with it then I got the K40 Co2 laser  and its not only the power but you can move mirrors a lot faster than large diode lasers with heat sinks and fans. High power fast movement you get wood to vaporize no ash nothing turning black just the wood gets engraved. What you got here is a wood Burning tool sure you can burn patterns with it but its not an engraving.

text:
I would love to hear your advice actually
I've been looking at your videos now for quite a while because I am getting more and more interested in buying my own laser cutter. I have a lot of experience with MDF as well as resin printers. Even before I used to go to the city workshop where I operated with their CO2 Laser (HyperCUT 6090 PRO).
 I can print a lot of things with my printers but still I would love to be able to cut and engrave stuff.. + with wood you get that warmer feeling if you give some sort of gift. I would love to have a machine that is capable of cutting good as well as engraving. Mostly I would cut some sort of stands and smaller chests or boxes for storage or decoration. material wise; Foam, MDF, acrylic and vinyl. So with this cutter it's really, really tempting. Price is fair, even though I was always in love with Co2 lasers and dreaming about getting one because of speed and enclosure and everything else. I also looked at some of your other videos like OM Tech K40 and its bigger 50w brother but with K40 the problem is cut volume and with 50w machines the problem is price. So if you were in my position, which machine would you recommend me getting? text:
You say that this is the most powerful Diode laser module in a system sold on the market right now but there's NEJE A40640 15W optical output laser listed for $239 (Shipping not included). They also have a complete system NEJE Master 2S Max with the A40640 module with a working area of 460√ó810mm listed for $579 (Shipping not included).

They have a claimed laser spot dimension of 0.04√ó0.04 mm and they sell a manual air assist addon for under $20.

Which is objectively a better deal than any of the systems you mention here.

text:
The software is very poor and limits your abilities to use this to its fullest capacity.  I bought it for the 10w laser, but had I known it would not use industry standard software, I would have made a different choice.
By the way, do not upgrade from laserbox basic 1.1.0 to 1.0.1 it breaks the positioning ability on the burn screen.  The earlier version works when you try to position the laser using the buttons to go left, right, up or down.  On the new release, it seems to be very harsh on the motors and the laser starts moving diagonally (not in a straight line) as intended.  Again, the software is beta release at best.

text: I want a laser capable of cutting a paint film off a copper PCB with really high resolution, cutting lines of 0.005" (5 thou) wide for making PCBs. Note the laser cuts the film off so it can be etched in the usual way. What's the best choice. I have an Atomstak 50 watt model and it is useless as the beam width is 0.015" in one plane and 0.025 in the other.
